name: runway-image-to-video
description: Animate any image by turning it into a video with motion effects or scene continuity. RunwayML’s I2V model transforms static visuals into short clips by extrapolating depth, movement, and temporal dynamics.

examples: The camera smoothly zooms in on the sleek, futuristic race car as it speeds through a neon-lit urban tunnel at twilight, its glossy white surface reflecting the vibrant pink and blue lights streaking past. The precise detailing of the car’s aerodynamic curves and glowing accents is highlighted as droplets of water spray from the spinning tires, adding a palpable sense of motion and intensity. The driver’s black helmet, contrasted against the car’s gleaming body, remains sharply in focus, emphasizing the thrilling high-speed chase through the city. The blurred cityscape and illuminated digital billboards in the background create a high-tech, cyberpunk atmosphere, intensifying the scene’s adrenaline and futuristic vibe.

name: hunyuan-image-to-video
description: Hunyuan I2V takes a static image and generates realistic video animations by interpreting motion and context. It works well for human portraits, objects, or scenes, adding lifelike movement while maintaining the image's integrity.

examples: The camera begins with a slow, deliberate zoom out from the figure standing on the rain-soaked rooftop, revealing the sleek, armored silhouette clutching a glowing katana that pulses with ominous red light. The deep blues and purples of the wet cityscape set a moody, cyberpunk atmosphere, with neon signs in vibrant pinks, blues, and oranges casting reflections on the glistening surfaces below. The mist and rain softly blur the distant buildings and streetlights, emphasizing the isolation of the lone warrior framed against the sprawling urban expanse. As the camera pulls back, the subtle hum of the futuristic city grows louder, immersing the viewer in a world of tension and anticipation, where danger lurks in the glowing depths of the rain-drenched streets.

name: gpt-5-nano
description: GPT-5 Nano is a lightweight, high-speed language model from the GPT-5 family designed for instant text generation. It delivers intelligent, context-aware responses for creative writing, summarization, dialogue, code generation, and automation — all at low latency and cost. Perfect for chatbots, assistants, content tools, and real-time applications that need fast, reliable text output.

examples: Write a short story about a time traveler who accidentally visits the wrong century and becomes a painter instead of a scientist.
prompt.description: Text prompt describing the text.
prompt.title: Prompt
prompt.name: prompt

examples:
Arin Vale hadn’t intended to land in a painting, and certainly not in Florence during the drift of a season’s end when the city wore the yellow of sunlit plaster like a tired old coin. The Chronometer—a ring of copper etched with constellations and a dial that heated when you spoke of future weather—had promised a jump to 2087, where climate data braided with city planning and time itself kept a tidy ledger. Instead, when the device coughed and winked, Arin found their breath tasting of olive oil and dust, and the square before them stretching with columns and awnings that seemed to lean toward the light. It was the year 1532, or so a street peddler claimed when Arin asked for the date in a voice that trembled with disbelief.

The city wore the scent of hot stone, wet pigments, and a rumor of rain that would never come that day. The Chronometer’s hum faded to a polite sigh and then to silence, leaving Arin with nothing but a marble-slick sense of wrongness and a backpack full of instruments that felt absurdly fragile in this world of bread ovens and open wells. Arin had studied weather, cycles, and the way a city breathed when the wind turned from the east; here, the wind carried dust from the river and the gossip of apprentices circling a wooden scaffold.

The first sight that snagged Arin’s eye wasn’t a clock or a river, but a painter’s studio tucked into a narrow alley where the sun pressed two fingers of light through the window. A man with a brush held in an oddly practiced grip—hands stained brown with pigment and a stubborn line of ink at the corner of his mouth—stood over a panel of fish scales and gesso. On the easel, a city of lines and shadow seemed to ripple in the heat. Arin clutched the Chronometer, then slipped it into a pocket and stepped closer. The air was bright with the sting of pigment and sweat, and for a fraction of a breath, Arin felt something like a spark flare: not the cold certainty of a scientist verifying a model, but the warm, listening curiosity of someone who could learn a life by looking.

“Signore,” Arin began, using the Italian the device had suggested was polite, though it sounded strange in their own mouth. “I am not here to steal, only to learn.” The painter looked up, eyes narrowing not with suspicion so much as a wary suspicion of a stranger’s intent.

The master—named Lorenzo, as the apprentice introduced him later—had a workshop that breathed like a living thing: a breath of resin and oil, a chorus of scraping brushes, the soft clack of a cup against a saucer, a cat that slept in a sunbeam and woke with a stretch. The apprentice, a wiry girl with a fringe of hair that kept slipping into her eyes, watched Arin with a mix of fearless curiosity and polite reserve. They were not in a place where you announced you came from the future; you were in a place where you earned bread by the brush and a patron’s smile by not asking questions about distant skies.

“I am a student of the heavens,” Arin found themselves saying, perhaps to fill the silence, or perhaps because the lie felt safer than the truth. “I study how light travels, how colors shift, how a city ages in a season.” It was not a lie exactly—just an oblique path to the real truth, which was that Arin had intended to bring back measurements that might guide cities to survive heat and flood. But the word “heavens” hung there like a question mark, inviting a response.

The studio talk shifted as the apprentice—whose name was Mara—grinned and nudged Arin toward the palette. “We mix pigments,” Mara said, half-chiding, half-welcoming. “We do not measure time, yet we count it by the number of days a painting holds a breath.” It was a way to say: this is how you learn to see, not to calculate.

Arin fell into painting as if waking from a dream of a city flooded with data. They learned to grind pigments with a mortar, to bind them with egg and resin, to temper panels until they sang with a certain readiness to accept a story. The studio smelled of almonds and dogwood, of sun-bleached linen and the old, stubborn truth that paint can carry more than color: it can carry a memory of light. The scientific mind kept trying to map the pigments, to catalog the layers, to compare different whites—lead white, white earth, ochre, and the pale luminosity that glowed in a sunset. But in the rhythm of the day—the lifting of a veil of dust from a balcony, the way the light pressed on the corner of a doorway, the quiet arithmetic of perspective—Arin found another calculation that mattered more: how to see.

Days bled into weeks, and Arin’s identity shifted from traveler of futures to student of the past’s pigment. They learned to measure distance with a painter’s eye, to coax light into a canvas by building gentle geometry into the frame. The master was strict, yet kind, and Mara teased a bright, stubborn fondness that suggested Arin might stay, not because the machine broken beyond repair was a fate, but because the life of canvas and color offered a kind of certainty the future had never granted.

One morning, finished with a study of a street corner, Arin stood back from a panel and realized something: the data they had anxiously carried in their mind—the climate curves and the models of storm tracks—had not vanished; they had learned to translate that data into something that could travel without a machine. Light, in this era, did not travel in the same way as across the hundreds of miles of a modern map; it finished its journey on the eye, and the eye, in turn, finished the journey on the canvas. Arin’s notes grew less scientific and more lyrical: a chart of shadows, a graph of brightness across the day, a narrative of color that moved like weather.

The moment of conversion came on a night when the studio was open to the patrons of the square, a small gallery night that felt like a pulse in the living heart of the city. A duke’s courier arrived with a commission for a painting of the city as it might be seen in a calm year, a future year, a year that could coax both greed and gratitude from the onlookers. The master asked Arin to lead the effort, to be the one who translated the moonlight and the bustle into something that could tell a story with eyes instead of instruments.

Arin did not begin by describing climate models or sea-salt winds; instead, they painted a scene that hummed with life. A street, at dusk, where the lamp light spilled golden on the stones, and in a corner stood a figure, half-inside, half-outside the painting, gazing toward a city’s far horizon. The figure bore the faintest suggestion of something not quite human: a silhouette of a man with a ring on his finger, a ring that seemed to glow with an inner weather—the kind of glimmer Arin had studied in spectral diagrams but never before dared to translate into color. The painting was not a direct forecast but a language of possibility—an image that might be seen and felt by someone who did not know the science, yet who understood the weather in a way the sciences never fully captured.

When the duke’s men returned to view the work, they whispered about color, about light, about how the painting held a breath that would not end. The master’s face, usually a mask of quiet pride, softened into something close to reverence. Mara clapped softly, and the courtyard of that evening rang with the muted sound of approving voices.

Arin began to suspect something might happen to them beyond the studio’s doors: a choice about a future that no longer belonged to a future-borne traveler but to a person who had found a home in a medium that could outlive a century. The Chronometer hummed again one night when a storm rolled over the city. It flickered with a stubborn glow, and Arin stood at the window, watching rain strike the tiles with a patient, rhythmic clap. The device begged for recalibration, begged for permission to rewrite a path. But Arin did not reach for it. The work offered an answer that a formula never could: art as a mapping of time, not the timekeeper itself.

The decision unfolded in a quiet scene, a late-evening studio with the last ember of the day glowing in the oil lamp. Mara and Lorenzo asked if Arin would stay, to teach the apprentices and to help sustain the studio that had become more a crossroads of memory than a business. There was a murmur, as if the walls themselves were listening, waiting for a consent. Arin looked at the room—the brushes, the jars, the stacked canvases that glowed softly in the lamplight—and felt something like a verdict pressed into their bones: I will stay. Not to study the future by force of a machine, but to honor the present the way light honors a surface, by staying until the moment it reveals itself fully.

The Chronometer never sang again. Not in public, not in Arin’s presence. It remained a stubborn, inert ring that hummed whenever Arin brushed a stroke to the edge of a panel. Some days, Arin wondered if it would ever function again, and some days, the painting seemed to answer: you already did the work you needed to do.

Years later, visitors would walk through the studio and see Arin’s canvases: panels that glowed with the quiet brilliance of season and streetlight, portraits that kept a city’s memory alive in oil and pigment, landscapes of weather made not in data but in the way light waited on stone. People spoke of Arin as a painter who could listen to the atmosphere and translate it into color with a science that was not a set of measurements but a discipline of perception.

Sometimes a scholar would come to study the painter’s technique, to trace how Arin’s early fascination with charts and graphs had become a different kind of chart—a map of perception, where time was measured not by clocks but by the shifting quality of light across a canvas. In those moments, Arin would smile and say nothing about the Chronometer, except that time traveled in the mind when the eye learned to see what science could not fully capture.

In a small ledger kept behind a false drawer in the studio, there is a line written in Arin’s hand: Time is not only something that happens to us; it is something we learn to paint. The page is spare, almost shy, but it hints at a pact: that to arrive in a century unplanned can be a misfortune or a revelation, and that sometimes a traveler’s greatest duty is to learn a language that makes the world legible to the heart.

If you stood before one of Arin’s late works and asked what it meant, you might hear a soft answer: a voice as gentle as a lamp’s glow and as certain as a line that won’t bend. It would tell you nothing of dates or weather models, but everything about looking, about how a life can pivot when the world invites you to see differently. And if you listened long enough, you might hear the city answering back—a chorus in pigment, a chorus of shadows that says, in the old tongue of light and matter, that time travels not only through years but through what we choose to hold onto: the moment when a traveler trades a laboratory for a studio, and discovers that the best way to change the future is to paint it, one careful stroke at a time.

Camera: Wide underwater → tracking floating jellyfish → macro on bubbles.

Motion/Physics: Water currents gently sway characters; bubbles rise naturally; floating cakes wobble lightly.
Audio: Bubbling water + faint harp melody; line: “Tea, my dear friends, before it drifts away.”

prompt: A cinematic, ultra-realistic 4K video featuring a lone, powerful male figure standing heroically on a dramatic, jagged cliff edge. The man is muscular, wearing dark, futuristic-fantasy armor with subtle blue and purple glowing accents, and a long, dark cape that flows dynamically in a gentle wind. He faces away from the camera, gazing over a vast, sprawling cyberpunk city at night. The city below is a breathtaking metropolis of towering skyscrapers, illuminated by vibrant neon lights predominantly in purple, pink, and electric blue hues, creating a stunning sci-fi aesthetic. The sky above is dark and stormy, filled with ominous clouds. Throughout the scene, dramatic bolts of white-blue lightning intermittently flash across the distant sky, revealing distant mountains and illuminating the cloud cover. Around the character's feet and the cliff edge, ethereal purple and blue magical energy pulsates and flows, accompanied by small, glowing orange sparks and embers rising into the air. The camera executes a slow, deliberate zoom out combined with a gentle, sweeping dolly movement, gradually expanding the view to emphasize the immense scale of the city and the hero's solitary presence against the epic backdrop. The overall mood is epic, mysterious, awe-inspiring, and slightly melancholic, blending sci-fi, fantasy, and superhero genres with a high-fidelity, cinematic finish.

name: z-image-turbo
description: Z-Image Turbo is a high-speed text-to-image model optimized for fast creative generation. It produces detailed, high-contrast, high-resolution images with strong stylization control. Ideal for rapid concept creation, visual exploration, product ideas, fantasy scenes, and cinematic composition tests. Designed for low latency and strong prompt adherence.

examples: A colossal glass hourglass floating in a dark void, filled not with sand but with glowing galaxies swirling inside. Each galaxy emits colorful nebula clouds that leak through cracks in the glass, forming cosmic streams drifting into the darkness. Bright rim lighting around the hourglass, reflective glass surfaces, deep space background, ultra-detailed sci-fi render, 8k quality, volumetric glow, high contrast.

name: flux-2-dev
description: Flux 2 Dev is a powerful text-to-image diffusion model designed for high-quality, fast, and highly detailed visual generation. It excels at creating cinematic lighting, vibrant compositions, surreal concepts, characters, products, and worlds with strong prompt following and artistic control. Ideal for rapid image ideation, visual storytelling, and concept art.

examples: A giant mechanical butterfly made of chrome wings and glowing blue energy veins, hovering above a mirror-smooth lake during twilight. Each wing reflects the sky while emitting soft neon trails. The lake surface ripples lightly from the energy pulses. Mist rolls across the water, and distant mountains fade into a deep violet horizon. Ultra-realistic lighting, cinematic composition, 8k render, high contrast, reflective metal textures.

name: flux-2-flex
description: Flux-2-Flex Text-to-Image is a flexible, high-fidelity generative model capable of producing detailed, imaginative, and stylistically rich scenes from text alone. It excels at surreal concepts, fantasy environments, sci-fi structures, cinematic atmospheres, and high-resolution artistic compositions with strong prompt adherence.

examples: A monumental crystalline arch towering above an endless desert of shifting silver sand, glowing with internal prisms that refract rainbow beams across the dunes. Beneath the arch floats a slowly rotating orb of condensed starlight, casting long ethereal shadows. In the distance, colossal sand whales breach from metallic dunes, their bodies shimmering with mirrored scales. Overhead, a fractured moon illuminates the scene with cold blue radiance. Ultra-detailed fantasy–sci-fi fusion, cinematic wide-angle view, volumetric light rays, 8k clarity, high contrast, dreamlike atmosphere.

name: flux-2-pro
description: Flux-2-Pro Text-to-Image is a premium, high-fidelity generative model capable of producing ultra-realistic, cinematic, and deeply detailed images from text prompts. It excels at complex lighting, layered compositions, surreal visual concepts, and professional art-grade rendering suitable for concept art, advertising visuals, and world-building.

examples: A colossal throne forged from intertwining meteor-iron branches, floating above a storm-torn ocean. Each branch pulses with glowing red runes, casting fiery reflections across the churning waves below. Above the throne hovers a massive eclipsed sun, its corona exploding into swirling arcs of molten light. Lightning erupts from the clouds and climbs the metal branches like living serpents. A lone hooded figure stands at the edge of the water, cloak whipping in the wind, illuminated only by the molten eclipse. Ultra-cinematic composition, hyper-detailed textures, 8k resolution, dramatic contrast, dark epic fantasy atmosphere.

Beneath the serpent, a crystalline ring structure orbits the shattered moon, reflecting cosmic beams in intricate patterns. The background is a star field swirling into a spiral galaxy, with vibrant energy storms crackling along the horizon. Ultra-cinematic cosmic fantasy, high contrast, 8k detail, volumetric glow, deep space atmosphere.

description: Any LLM is a versatile large language model for text generation, comprehension, and diverse NLP tasks such as chat and summarization. Ready-to-use REST inference API, best performance, no coldstarts, affordable pricing.

temperature.description: This setting influences the variety in the model’s responses. Lower values lead to more predictable and typical responses, while higher values encourage more diverse and less common responses. At 0, the model always gives the same response for a given input.

max_tokens.title: Max Tokens
max_tokens.name: max_tokens
max_tokens.description: This sets the upper limit for the number of tokens the model can generate in response. It won’t produce more than this limit. The maximum value is the context length minus the prompt length.

examples:
Transformers are a type of neural network architecture that revolutionized large language models by enabling them to process sequences of data efficiently. They achieve this using a mechanism called "attention," which allows the model to weigh the importance of different parts of the input sequence when processing each element. Instead of processing words in a strictly sequential order, like previous models, transformers can look at all words in a sentence simultaneously and determine their relationships to each other. This parallel processing makes them much faster and better at understanding long-range dependencies within text.

Example: Consider the sentence "The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog."

When a transformer processes the word "fox," it doesn't just look at "brown" before it. It can simultaneously look at "jumped" and "dog" to understand the full context. The attention mechanism might assign higher importance (higher "attention") to "jumped" and "dog" when determining the meaning of "fox" in that sentence, realizing "fox" is the subject performing the action "jumped" on "dog." This allows it to understand that "fox" is an animal doing an action, rather than just a word in isolation.

The glow from the screens reflects off chairs and glass walls, creating a quiet, unsettling atmosphere. Cinematic realism, restrained motion, strong contrast between darkness and screen light, modern near-future tone.

name: kling-v3.0-pro-text-to-video
description: Kling 3.0 Pro is a high-end video generation model capable of producing longer, smoother, and more realistic cinematic videos with strong motion consistency. It handles complex scenes, realistic physics, natural camera movement, and detailed environments better than earlier versions.

examples: A lively street market in the early morning. Vendors arrange fresh fruits and vegetables on wooden stalls, steam rises from food carts, and people walk past carrying bags and coffee cups. Sunlight slowly breaks through between buildings, casting warm light and soft shadows. A bicycle passes through the frame, cloth awnings sway gently in the breeze, and the camera moves forward at walking pace. Realistic motion, natural lighting, cinematic but grounded.

name: kling-v3.0-standard-image-to-video
description: Kling 3.0 Standard Image-to-Video animates a single input image into a short, realistic video with smooth, stable motion. It prioritizes temporal consistency, natural physics, and subtle camera movement, making it ideal for everyday scenes, travel moments, people, vehicles, and calm cinematic shots.

examples: The hamster begins on the left side of the tabletop and quickly runs across the surface toward the right. Its tiny legs move rapidly, body bouncing slightly with natural motion. As it runs, the sunflower seeds blur slightly beneath it. The hamster slows near the bowl, stops, and stands upright to grab a seed. The camera remains fixed, depth of field stays shallow, and lighting remains soft and consistent for a realistic, cute result.

name: kling-v3.0-standard-text-to-video
description: Kling 3.0 Standard Text-to-Video generates smooth, realistic videos from text with stable motion and natural behavior. It works best with clear subjects, simple actions, and one continuous scene, making it ideal for cute animals, small actions, and calm cinematic moments.

examples: A close-up view of a mechanical watch lying open on a dark surface. As the video plays, the internal gears begin turning smoothly, tiny springs flex and release, and the balance wheel oscillates rhythmically. Light reflections glide across polished metal parts while the camera slowly pans sideways, revealing the layered precision of the mechanism. Studio lighting, macro detail, clean background, calm and satisfying motion.
